text: Just stopped in for the first time last week to try the Chicken Pad Thai. It was very fresh, served hot and delicious. My only suggestion is that they offer a lunch special with soup or an egg roll. The portion itself was quite filling though. Nice, quiet atmosphere - only a few tables but it was a pleasant place to sit and relax.

Food and environment brought me back to Thailand! Noodle soups are authentic Thai food.  My Tom Yum noodle soup was very similar to the street foods of Thailand except this portion is so much larger and costs more. There was also extras on the noodles that's included such as squid & meatballs. Glad I got to try this place; there were Thais dining here so you know it's gotta be good!  Pretty empty for a Sunday lunch so service was good. Food came out fast. First Thai restaurant I've been to that has different price for Thai tea with or without ice, with or without condensed milk. You can either pay $5 or $2, depending on what you get on it. Interesting concept.  Every table has condiment jars with pickled peppers, dried chili peppers. They gave us plastic cup, plate, and a teaspoon for my toddler. How thoughtful of them!

I'm a great fan of Thai food and had great expectations when visiting this restaurant. We were ravenous by the time we reached the restaurant and quickly ordered Chicken Satay, Thai Crispy Rolls, Pad Kee Mao and Hot & Spicy Fried Rice. Chicken Satay - It's my all-time favorite and absolutely liked it here with yummy peanut sauce. Thai Crispy Rolls - This is the first time I'm having this and it's very good with crispy exterior and tasty meat and glass noodles inside. Pad Kee Mao - It could have been better as I felt it's too sweet. Hot & Spicy Fried Rice - It's a winner. The flavors are so good with all the vegetables and chicken in it. You can add some dried chili powder if you like the fried rice to be extra spicy. The service is pretty good and we will definitely visit again to devour their tasty food :-)

Did not like the food at all.  TomYam soup - bland Mee Krob - too sweet, your tongue hurts Salmon dish - way too salty and salmon too dry Pad Thai - all you can taste is peanut flavor in the sauce The only thing I liked about this place is that it's a BYOB restaurant.

WORST SERVICE EVER. Waited over an hour to even get our drinks. I asked the waitress how long food would take and she doesn't even come back. I waited another 30 minutes, but nope never comes to our table. The restaurant was not even packed or busy. I had to had to walk out.

I'm going to keep this short and sweet. I had their peanut sauce chicken dish with rice (Thai rice is just better btw.)  My body wants more,  I'm an instant junkie.  I don't know if they strategically place msg in their dishes but I can't stop thinking about this dish and it has only been 40 minutes since I scarfed it down.  This may come across as hyperbole but I love this place so much that Rosded might be the place I'd pick for "Check Please."  I mean everyone else would be trying to impress with ambiance and decor from Michellin wannabe places......this place is like $10 with a tip and you are left beside yourself plus the M recognition (according to the sticker on their door.)  So would I come back?  Sure, I might even go back tonight.  I would bath in their food if possible and build a shrine in my house for this dish.  (I'm going to breath now)

I normally default to Opart Thai when in Lincoln Square, but decided to give Rosded a spin for this afternoon's lunch. Although Opart makes a great curry, Rosded took takes it up a few notches. The ingredients of the chicken curry blended together perfectly and the chicken was juicy and flavorful. From now on I will now default to Rosded as my top choice for Thai in the square!

Terrible experience here. I have a gluten intolerance and usually thai food is safe. I asked the server (who looked like a manager/owner too) if a couple dishes are gluten free (spring rolls and curry), and he abruptly and exasperatedly said "I don't know." When I asked if he could ask someone, he said "they won't know." I wound up ordering pad thai, but it was not good pad thai. Not good quality meat either. I shouldn't have ordered anything.

Simple place, amazing Thai food. Nothing against Opart Thai, but I couldn't believe how many more positive reviews they receive compared to Rosded. I got the exact same order at both places in the same week, and Opart's food was consistently oversweetened and overcooked, more of an "Americanized" version of Thai cuisine.  If you want delicious, authentic Thai food in the area, go here!

So good and fresh. Looks like nothing special when you first walk in, but they are so friendly, and the food is flavorful and delicious.  We had the Panang curry with chicken and the spicy basil with ground chicken. Highly recommend both.

I'm from Wisconsin, but on our way into the city my parents and I ventured to Roseded for a trip down memory lane. My mom went to this place THIRTY YEARS ago in college and has maintained that it's the best fish she's ever had. We went there today to confirm that it wasn't in fact just nostalgia driving this claim. Alas, this hole-in-the-wall does have the best fish of my young 22-year-old life. We shared the red snapper with basil and chilies. Crisped to perfection and generously doused with a spicy sugar glaze, this dish really hit it out of the park. When my mom went three decades previously, they served the whole fish bones and all. Now, it's just the filet, which makes for an easier, albeit slightly less authentic eat.  Our server also recommended a mango rice desert for a light summer treat. The green rice is colored with pandan, a tropical leaf. Coated with sweet coconut milk, the warm rice pairs well with the cool mango. I don't even care that I left the place a few pounds heavier, because everything was so incredibly fresh and full-bodied. I'll be back, Roseded!

Ordered take out from here and it was delicious and inexpensive. The crispy Thai rolls and potstickers were especially delicious! The server who helped us seemed rather grumpy so I'm not sure I'd enjoy eating in as much, but it's still a solid Thai restaurant.

I used to come here all the time and then they sold the place and now it's under new management. After about three years and reading the Yelp reviews I decided to give it another try. Honestly it was just so-so. The service could be better and the food was just not great. I got chicken satay which was super greasy and somewhat bland. Got shrimp rolls and they were pretty good, came out hot and crunchy. Also had salmon green curry, the salmon was invisible but the dish over all was pretty good. I also got tum yum soup (no meat, tofu) it was actually the worst I've had. It had no veggies at all and was way too sweet. Overall if the service was better I might consider coming back but the one (yes one) server was not very attentive, she looked pissed off half the time and looked over unamused. It's a shame because I work in the service industry and like to be generous but this time it was strictly 15%.

I would give 5 stars but the service could be better... Get the green curry tofu! So good!  I Asked for spicy and I wasn't disappointed.  My coworker got the chicken pad Thai and said it was one of his favorites.  Don't expect a fancy joint. It's a small affordable place with good food!
Absolutely delicious!! Some of my favorite Thai food in Lincoln Square.  I love their soup and their pad thai is on point! It is a very small, friendly restaurant.

Wonderful, tiny- almost hole in the wall - neighborhood spot for homemade Thai food.  The bone-in chicken with rice served with cucumber salad (sorry, can't remember the Thai name) is hearty and delicious.  Prices are cheap.  Service is very nice.  I can't wait to eat here again.  Plus it's BYOB and there's an amazing little wine shop next door - Augusta food and wine - which has a superb, expert handpicked selection with many wines at a reasonable price.
Delicious every time. The kee mao is my favorite in the city.

Good Thai food in Lincoln Square at reasonable prices.   Menu has all the Thai greatest hits.   Dining room is nothing to write home about, but service is friendly and fast.    Great place to grab a quick bite to eat.

I have been eating at this place for years and finally wanted to right a review. I love the food, Thai food at its best. They listen to me if I request, "easy on the sauce", "extra on a particular vegetable".  I feel it's home cooking in a comfortable little place that feels like a great escape from other local places.  Mixed vegetable dish with tofu or chicken is my staple dish. Thank you Rosded for all the great years of great food and service!

After many visits to nearby Opart Thai and often driving past Rosded, I'm glad we dined here instead.  Very quaint, clean, at-home atmosphere without all the fancy decor.  There were at most 10 small tables which allowed us to have a decent dinner conversation without shouting over nearby diners or loud music.   We ordered the cucumber salad to start, which was a very generous portion and tasted just like Mom's :)   For dinner we had the Pad See Ew and Traditional Fried Rice. Both were delicious! Pad See Ew was authentic and not overly sweet as most Americanized versions sadly are.  The Fried Rice was tasty! We will be back to try other dishes, which I hear can be customized to your level of spiciness.  I overheard one patron asking for "Thai Spicy!" While I am far from challenging my taste buds to that extreme, I'm glad the owners/chef is accommodating.  Food was so good, it slipped my mind to take pics of our dishes before eating everything off the plate! Space is tight and there is only one chef and waitstaff I believe, so don't expect to be in and out in a hurry.  But the food is definitely worth the wait! For a delicious home cooked meal without all the unnecessary frills, don't pass this place up!

A hole in the wall but the food is so good! It's very authentic but you need to be with a thai person to get good thai dishes. They have a Thai menu that for thai patrons. I love their kuay jub and yen ta fo!

Totally authentic Thai food. This place has been around since 1976 - well before Opart, Spoon, Sticky Rice or any of the other Thai restaurants near Lincoln Square. Must try that you may not get elsewhere - Rich Green beef (named after a loyal customer), Rosded noodles and basil duck. And the prices are very reasonable. Also BYOB. It's not a huge place but great food and a cozy environment. Definitely not the place if you want fancy but can you taste fancy? Come for the authentic Thai food!

A friend and I stopped in for dinner before an event at the Book Cellar. The prices were average, the menu was average/typical  (besides the fact that we were craving crab rangoon, which they didn't have), and the portions were average. The service was good. Overall, no complaints but it won't be topping out Spoon or Aroy.

Was hoping this would be my new Thai place since I just moved in down the street but it wasn't anything great. The place is kind of a dump and the same food is definitely better elsewhere in the neighborhood.

Rosded is a fantastic little spot directly across from the Western brown line stop.  It's a convenient place to grab take out after work, or to bring a few friends and a bottle of wine.   If you dare the waiter to make the spiciest curry possible, or a 10 out of 10 on the "thai spicy scale", beware.  He will take you up on the challenge, and will enjoy watching your face turn bright red as he returns to fill up your water glass.   The Som Tum is delicious.  It has just the right amount of tang and spice.  The pad thai is consistently good.  And the red curry can be made as spicy as you want it, which is awesome.
Fast, good service. Cute little place. Delicious Pad Thai.

The food is well-portioned and of good quality, and inexpensive. The small dining room is a little bit chilly, but once you have a nice pot of Jasmine tea in front of you, you'll forget about that. The spring roll appetizers are fresh, crunchy, and come with a delicious sauce. If you're a meat eater, don't miss the Combo Fried Rice, because it's delicious, and the meat is good quality and plentiful. Waitstaff is very nice. Don't pass this little place by, try it.
I had a really good time with the green Thai curry rice.  It was very spicy.  If you don't like spicy you shouldn't order it.

This place is one of my go-tos when I want soup. Their Rosded soup is very delish. It reminds me of pho, but without noodles. One gripe I have is it seems like the price has risen, and the portion has recently decreased. However, because of the deliciousness and fact that it's low carb (bonus) I will continue to get it! I also have had their spring rolls, which were not what I expected, and not the kind I prefer. My boyfriend got the pad see ewe once and it was very good.

I've been eating at this restaurant since 2005. Unlike most Thai restaurant that put a ton of sugar to make every dish sweet, their food was very good and authentic (I had lived in Thailand for years). Many Thai people eat there. You can imagine how authentic the food must be. The price is very affordable. It's 2014 now but back in 2005 I used to get a noodle dish for $4.98! The cheapest dish there is about 7 or 8 bucks which is still not bad. The server is polite. Highly recommended.

No frills, just lots of flavor. And they know how to really spice their dishes up. Tom yam goong spiced just enough to make you sweat. Salmon green curry that goes beyond the  usual curry heat with what I can best describe as floral - from the fragrant Thai basil. And the price can't be beat- dinner always costs about $10 including tip. Love Rosded!

This review is geared towards the food only, as I've only ordered takeout. I've tried the red and panang curries, both with tofu. The Good: The red curry was just average. Very mild with your standard red curry flavor. There was a smattering of red and green bell peppers and a surfeit of bamboo pieces (straws? strips? they were thin like linguine and short--kind of annoying). The tofu was cut into thick blocks, which were way too ungainly to eat whole, or even halved. I'm not too particular about the shape/size of the tofu, but it is an important component to consider when it makes up 50-70% of your curry contents. The Bad: As for the panang curry, I'm sad to report that it was completely inedible. The flavor was absolutely repulsive. I tried to keep an open mind and give it a few tries--maybe this is what panang should taste like? maybe I've been deceived by ALL the other panang curries I've tried over the years at VARIOUS establishments--but no, it was just as foul-tasting the second, third, and fourth tastes. Too bad, Rosded, this is a dealbreaker. To top it off, I was unimpressed with the ratio of tofu to vegetable (which was all tofu and no vegetable, practically). It looked like an entire block of tofu was swimming in curry. The Ugly: My ultimate beef is with the rice portions. They give you one small scoop of rice. Small as in "we're rationing rice because it is wartime and the government asked its citizens to make drastic cuts"-small. It was nowhere near enough to accompany an entire bowl of curry. Pretty stingy, Rosded. I used two of your "portions" for one dish. Conclusion:  I will not be patronizing this restaurant in the future. It boils down to the curry being such a let-down, the rice portions abysmally small, and the fact that they aren't on the Seamless app and don't seem to have an updated menu online anywhere. Time to step up your game, Rosded.

My partner and I were wandering the area looking for a new restaurant to eat at. We always love Thai cuisine and the reviews for this place seemed alright. Well we were sadly mistaken.  As we walked in we were crammed between a two door entrance which was quite unnecessary. No one said hello or greeted us so we sat ourselves down and the waitress came to us and gave us menus. My partner ordered the green curry with chicken and I ordered the chicken fried rice. For one I'm pretty sure that green curry is not suppose to have an oily film , nor be filled with a ton of spices to make it inedible with an overbearing taste of jelapenos. And my chicken fried rice was in fact not fried rice. It was white rice that they threw some stuff on, and barely any veggies.  As we continued to eat I examined the restaurant as a whole. The walls were dirty, the windows were uncleaned, and the tables had all mismatching chairs. When it came time to pay, we looked over to find her eating her food (which wasn't even the restaurant food.. Food from home) and talking with her friend while texting. We had to call her over to get our check. When sh came by, she asked if we needed a box which we kindly replied no thank you and smiled but she walked away with a rude attitude and brought the check.  Needless to say, I have no understanding as to how any of these good reviews came about, but this place was down right awful. I wouldn't not recommend this place to anyone who doesn't want an upset stomach and a bad taste left in there mouth.
Authentic, delicious and excellent service.  I would highly recommend this restaurant.

The food is great and the portions are pretty big too.  Our server was friendly and the prices were extremely reasonable, especially considering how large the portions are. Two of us split the spring roll, two small bowls of soup, and one large bowl of soup- I guess we were in a soup mood and they all sounded so good!  I took at least two servings of soup home with me. I will definitely return.

As we had mostly completed our Western Ave thai crawl, it was time to branch out to non-Western Ave places. This particular place is just off Western. VERY TRICKY. This place was average but could maybe be better if we ordered other things. I got my usual crazy spicy noodles and also sampled the pad thai. The menu is kinda funny because it just says "vegetables" instead of actually telling you what's in each dish, so every noodle dish just reads "noodles, vegetables, egg". My particular iteration of spicy noodles had cabbage in it, which was a surprise. Anyway taste was good but slightly less flavorful than the other thai places in town (literally just down the street), and definitely less spicy. They have some sauces on the table, maybe I should have played with those. Also the food came out nice and hot. I guess it was more homestyle delicious, as opposed to restaurant delicious, if that makes sense. In the sea of Thai restaurants, they did not stand out but I would not be opposed to coming here again. I'm just not sure why I would choose it vs the 3-4 other places that are super close by. Also note, the yelp menu for this place as of 5/7/14 is outdated. average noodle entree price was $8 or so. Also BYOB.

It's like eating in your asian friends' parents' kitchen. Authentic and home-cooked. Peanut spring rolls - was fine. The sauce wasn't as creamy as I wished.  Crispy spring rolls - smaller size and tasty. Tom Yum Soup - one of the best I had. Hot and not too spicy. BBQ Fried Rice - true true Thai Fried Rice. The only dish we really finished. Chicken Larb - pretty good. Ordered sticky rice and it never came with the dish.  Supreme - Do Not Order - we called it their hodge podge. Tasteless. I do really like it here. It only seats 27 people and it closes at 9 pm. BYOB - liquor store across the street.  Great place to try a lot of everything.

Great Thai food.  We happened to be in the area and was looking for something kids would like.  Came across this small place near Lincoln square.  That was one of our best Thai experiences.  Their pad Thai and crab fried rice were the best of what we tried.

I love Rosded, have been coming here for perhaps four years.  It is my favorite thai in the city, and reminds me most of food I've eaten in Bangkok.  My favorite dishes are the crispy fried tofu, the ground chicken salad with peanuts and big matchsticks of fresh ginger, the crab fried rice (swoon), and the fried catfish salad with apples (sounds odd but is really tasty if you like catfish.)  I haven't had anything, however, that I didn't enjoy.

Yum, yum, and yum again.  What the hell, add one more yum. Like eating the best quality Thai food prepared specially for you in the cook's home and served at their dining room table. Small, cozy, and delightful. And BYOB! There's a boutique wine shop two doors south, and a full-scale liquor store about a block west and across Western.  Yummily, Peter O. and S.

I am a Thai addict - I eat it at least 1-2 times per week. This is the best place in the area for Thai and that is saying a lot because there are a lot of good places in the area. The Penang cat fish and basil pork are my personal favorites, as well as the shrimp-papaya salad. Everything is excellent though so you can't go wrong. And the best part ... They actually make it extra spicy if you appreciate it that way. Enjoy!

2 legit 2 quit... ...going here. It's just so authentic. Fresh, spicy, and the real deal, y'all! Tasty Pad Thai with a great texture and plenty of veggies and egg. Spicy Basil Catfish flaky and fresh with some zingy sauce. The Chicken satay's peanut sauce is just the right consistency. Rad chicken noodle soup that is literally nature's elixir given the freezing weather and strong wind of Chicago. I love slurping it up to warm my bones.  The atmosphere is pretty wack but who cares right when it's so inexpensive, yummy, and LEGIT!?!  "Hey hey!"
Started with the shrimp rolls, followed by curry noodles and ended with some hot tea.  Fantastic food & service!

Never a bad call. For nearly 20 years this place has been rocking Thai Food in the Square and doing it well. Great place for a low key date.  When I lived in Lincoln Square, it was the 1990s, the Asian beetles had not killed all the trees yet, and houses were $175K and you heard German and Greek on the sidewalks, and Rosded was here - churning out solid Thai food for the neighborhood. On a recent visit the place was the same. Solid curries, amazing Pad Thai, and good Thai iced coffee. They have been here through the rise and fall of the German deli's and the rise of chains and investor driven bars and cafes, and seem to be here to stay.

People seem to love this place, but are they coasting on regulars and reputation?  They have no website, no independent or corporate online ordering, and they don't deliver.  The space is pretty small, but comfortable enough when they're not busy.  So the food must be really, really great, right? No.  My experiences have been up and down like all of the other numerous area Thai spots.  On the one hand, you have crispy shrimp rolls, plain but delicious.  On the other hand, you have really bland pad thai with lots of tofu but barely any peanuts.  Where are the peanuts, yo?  They must be saving them all for the rama noodles, which come doused in a peanut-coconut sauce which is actually pretty good but very heavy-handed.  Tom yam soup is enjoyable but unexceptional.  Plain old stir-fried mixed vegetables might actually be the best thing that I have found. So after two visits, I am crossing this one off the list and pushing forward in my increasingly futile quest to find a go-to Thai restaurant in Lincoln Square/Ravenswood.
Good food and prices. I had Pad Thai. Chicken was very tasty and the dish overall was just what I was looking for when I stopped in for lunch.

I've been going here for almost 15 years, so since I was 4 years old. Food has always been delicious, homemade, and fresh.  My favorites: Chicken noodle soup, Chicken sweet and sour, chicken fried rice, pot stickers, and chicken satay. You can't go wrong with any of these!

Small hole-in-the-wall restaurant. Easy to miss if you're not paying attention. This place has the best larb I've EVER had - super fresh and tangy! Also, their crazy noodles are delicious. I would also recommend this beef dish covered in garlic and vinegar goodness - I forgot what it was called but it was an awesome appetizer and I could eat it for days!! Very affordable, HUGE portions, and friendly staff/owners. I can't wait to come here again!

Came here at least two times so far.  Really depends on what you order here.  However, I'm sure there's something for everyone.  I love the peanut spring rolls, wonton soup, and noodles.  Came here cuz they often have groupon or some sort of deals.  Just make sure u let her know you want hot coffee.. my friend ordered coffee and she got a thai iced coffee... So she had to return it for a hot cup that tasted like water according to her.  lol.  Ok.. but I'm not sure I'd go again for anything else than what I've tried and liked.

Authentic Thai food. The owner is the waiter who owns the floor. Small restaurant with great food. Get here and wait for a table, it is worth it.  Get the Chix Satay for a true taste of Thailand.  My Thai wife thinks this one of two of the best restaurants in Chicago.  Get noodles, they are lighter than a typical Chinese wide noodle.  If you don't eat here, they will be ok. They have been here for 36 years and have a loyal following.  You will just miss out on GREAT Thai food.

I've been a regular customer at Rosded for years and it is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Everything on there menu is delicious but my dish of choice is the Pad Bamee (Egg noodles with bbq pork and veggies). The staff is very friendly and they work very hard. I only wonder why they haven't expanded to a larger place but I guess it wouldn't be the special little thai place that it has been for all these years.

Nice hole in a wall place for authentic Thai food.  I visit every once in a while, and I always leave full and happy.  Their satay pork appetizer is fantastic.  Their tom yum soup is mediocre, so maybe skip it.  Overall, the prices are cheap, and the service is friendly.

Oh my. Taste buds. Exploding. Memories in Thailand. Coming back. Memories. Oh my GOD!  Rosded was actually pretty hard  to find. Where the GPS told me it was didn't seem like there was anything there. So after parking and walking around for about 10 minutes we finally managed to find the place. And yay! It was pretty empty so we were able to get our food pretty quick. Hint for Thai readers is to ask for the Thai menu. I didn't actually compare it to the regular menu but sometimes I find it difficult to understand what the same word is in English but reading it in Thai made all the difference. I had dishes that I haven't had since I left Thailand and boy. Oh my. Taste buds. Exploding. Memories in Thailand. Coming back. Memories. Oh. My. GOD!!!  Seriously people, do yourselves a favor and go here. With that said, if you are going to compare it to your neighborhood thai restaurant with what you think is GREAT pad thai but is actually short of mediocre... I have nothing to say.
Have had dinner here a handful of times over the last three years - always ok & pleasant but also never impressed or great.  The portions, in my opinion, are on the smaller side.

This place is good. Authentic Thai food. I came here a couple of times.  Ive had the panang chicken which wasn't spicy at all..i think it will taste even better with some spice.  I also ordered their fish cake which came with 5 pieces, very good as appetizers.   The pad lad nar beef has a lot of gravy, beef is a just a little overcooked..but overall its still good. The dishes are not expensive for a large portion.
This place is amazing. I passed it a million times on my way to Opart Thai. So glad I finally tried it - I am now hooked.

Tom Kha soup was amazing. Spring Rolls with peanut sauce are worth skipping.  There was an obscene amount of peanut sauce slathered across the top of the rolls, way too much for my liking. Pad Woonsen was delicious.
Nice backup for Opart Thai.  BYOB and caring service.  The food was just average

Since I'm a full-blooded Thai chick born and raised in Chicago, I've eaten at my fair share of Thai restaurants so I'm pretty picky!!! This is the only place I eat Thai food in the city - so good - get the mussels they'll change your life!

The Thai iced tea is good, but wasn't impressed with the food. The spring rolls with peanut sauce were not that flavorful and the peanut sauce was very thick and oily. The portions were very generous but the pad Thai wasn't very flavorful, no lemon grass or ginger.

One of my favorite Thai Restaurants! Their curry soups are awesome as well as most of their other dishes. The venue can be a little cramped when they are busy but takeout is always a good alternative when you don't want to wait.
Roast duck is cooked with curry, something new for us.  And pad Thai is standard, beef is not so hard like some Thai restaurants.

Beef curry noodle - 5 stars Everything else was delicious as well including the papaya salad, but really I'll be back for the beef curry noodle.  It's so good that I dumped my rice into the left over curry sauce.  Good times.

Excellent authentic Thai Food here. Affordable pricing.  The restaurant have been here for so long and they could have expanded so many years ago so many times over - even before Opart's latest owner who did a marvelous job of turning Opart around. The food quality has been consistent all these years. Their pad Thai is better than most Thai restaurant. Not made in a rush, resulting in wet noodles. The noodles are a bit drier and more flavorful than most Pad Thai. Although this quality is not consistent. On a few visits we did get wetter noodles, we noticed during those times are when the restaurant is more packed. Although the restaurant is not as packed as it used to be, due to losing market share to Opart. The food is still pretty consistent. My favorite dish include: red snapper fillet. panang dishes, masamun, pad thai. The Thai Iced Coffee is great here. I wish other Thai restaurant sell red snapper fillet like Rosded, makes eating fish much more enjoyable when you don't have to pick out bones. Over the years the sauce for the snapper fillet has gotten thinner and a bit more salty but just as good. However I do prefer the old sauce, thicker and a bit more sweet.

Rosded has been around forever and to its credit has stayed pretty much the same. Food is pretty good though the last few times I've gone it's been slow to come out.  Prices are on par with other Thai restaurants. Overall, this place is not bad as an option if the other restaurants in the area are busy or if you want there Rosded soup.

The prices are comparable to other Thai restaurants in the chicagoland area. I do like the fact that they have a very diverse menu (and a menu in Thai).  We ordered the  1. boat noodles (Thai beef noodle soup). Wish they put more meat balls in it. Mine only had 1. Flavor was good. You can get any noodle you want. 2. Ten ta fo- Good flavor. Lots of seafood and the portion is huge. 3. Nam Tok Moo- Dish was a little too sweet for me and not spicy enough. We ordered sticky rice with it and it was so overcooked it was all sticking together like a wet glob. 4. Papaya salad- awesome! You can customize it if you'd like. We had them make it not spicy and sour. It came out exactly like we asked. 5. Wonton soup- broth was good.  The only thing with this place is that even with an empty restaurant, our food took almost 45 mins to make after we put in the order. It was just way too long for me.  Recap: Food- Pretty decent service- average prep time- needs improvement

Love this place!  Very reasonably priced and BYOB.  I haven't had something off the menu I didn't love.  It's a bit small on the inside, but it's never been packed.  One of Lincoln Square's best kept secrets.

I've noticed from previous reviews that all the low ratings are by non-Asians, which tells me that they prefer ketchup in their Pad Thai yet pretend to know what Thai cuisine should taste like.  Its inexpensive, incredibly delicious and based on those I give it five as most Thai places don't offer both.
Nice dishes, Taste real authentic. The owner is really nice. If you are looking for REAL Thai taste...this restaurant is definitely.

first and foremost... Thais don't eat with chopsticks...  we use a spoon and fork.  so I cringed when the table next to me asked for chopsticks.  we do however, use chopsticks with our noodle soups.  that is ok and they will bring out chopsticks for that, but otherwise don't ask for chopsticks!! anyway, on to the review of Rosded.  This is probably my family's favorite Thai restaurant in Chicago.  This place and Siam House in Niles are our two go to Thai restaurants.  There are a couple of warnings about this place though, one is there are about 10 tables in this small place, and only one waiter. So don't expect to be in and out quickly if the place fills up.  The other warning is that there are different chefs for different nights.  We have been there a few times where the food was definitely not up to par and other times it's been awesome. Some of our favorites here are the Som Tum (papaya salad), Nam Tok Beef with sticky rice, Fried Oysters, Rosded Noodle soup, and Bamee with BBQ Pork.   All in all, a really good and authentic Thai restaurant.  Very friendly service and great food and at a pretty decent price!  When my friends ask me where to go for Thai, I always recommend this place first. oh also, this place is BYOB, I always forget this...

I'd give this place 3.5 stars. Pretty good. The Rosded soup is amazing! The lad nar was good, just too many noodles and too much gravy. Could have used some more broccoli and chicken.  The ambiance is quite cozy and the staff is very helpful. I'll be going back for some different dishes.
A Fave! A weekly date with my tastebuds! The Tom Ka Kai Pineapple Fried Rice. etc etc great location great prices great food

Must have been an off night since others are giving them rave reviews.  Stopped by for some noodles and ordered the duck noodle soup. While the soup was tasty, the duck had a weird green metallic sheen to each piece. I don't know about you, but I was not about to eat a piece of GREEN meat, DISGUSTING!!  I will probably not go back, given the number of Thai restaurants in the neighborhood.

Its that time of month again! No, not that one. Its the time of month that my husband and I visit Chicagoland for an exhausting combination of (mainly) work and some fun. The fun part is typically limited to trying out a new place for dinner. Either I love food way too much, or my fun-o-meter is easily filled. You decide. Excited about the cultural melting pot the windy city is, we once again opted for an Asian dinner. So i quickly detached my phone from my figurative hip, and pulled up my trusty Yelp app.  "Best authentic Thai" in "Chicago, IL". Long list of restaurants? Check.  Always on the lookout for a small, hole-in-the-wall kinda place I figured I'd narrow it down to one dollar. After reading a couple of reviews (and running out of time on the express way) I navigated hubby to this highly regarded Thai restaurant in what appears to be a predominantly German neighborhood, go figure!  Imported Bavarian "May-tree" across the street, and all. Once inside I could only agree with previous reviewers, this place is indeed small, yet appeared to be surface clean *yay*. An official looking plaque hangs on the wall stating the maximum occupancy is 27, exceeding this number is 'hazardous and unlawful'. That should give you an idea as to the size of the dining room!  We started our meal off with a fresh cold spring roll with peanutsauce and an order of tom yum soup. Both were pretty good, the soup had a nice level of.sourness to it whereas the springroll was slightly on the bland side. The peanutsauce which is served atop is sweet and chunky. Very peanut-y, unfortunately I could not pick up on any other flavors such as lemongrass or a hint of spice or even creaminess. I am a fan of the more complex kind of peanutsauces. Sorry.  I have never been to Thailand, so I cannot speak for the authenticity of any of the dishes on the menu, or the items served. What I do know, is that my husbands Rosded special stir fry (I forgot the name, shame on me) had NO spice when ordered Hot, and the sauce itself tasted more American-Chinese than any Thai I have ever had. It faintly reminds me of your standard lo-mein flavor profile.  Another thing I know is that the green beans that came in this dish were raw, and the onions were very strong. Cooked at higher heat and for a little longer, the natural and delicious sweetness of this bulbous veggie wouldve come out and wouldve actually complimented the slightly sweet sauce, quite well. Lastly, I have a terrible petpeeve with corny shaped vegetables. You know, the run-of-the-mill and cheap-looking star/gear shaped carrots for example. Yeah, they were definitely represented! Also, their mushrooms are shaped like a certain male organ, which I hardly doubt is their fault- but entertaining nonetheless. Now, hubby enjoyed the overall flavor of the dish, so I am happy that he was happy! After studying Yelp (and the menu), I decided to go with the panang beef, ordered hot. My first plate came out like pieces of beef under a.layer.of.oil. Not appealing. When I asked the waiter if this dish is always served like this, I was told it was due to the peanutbutter? I will post a picture, and you can judge yourself about the plausibility of that claim. The sweet man immediately offered to reduce it, and the second plate came out MUCH better, see pic.  One bite and I was pleasantly surprised. The ghost of oilygreasypiecesofmeatgrossness made room for flavors that quite honestly danced on my tongue. Coconut, peanut, curry, basil and ireallydontcarewhatelse was a very satisfying combination that had me picking at my food long after I had reached the point of fullness.  Panang beef, definately a must try here! Friendly if not a little a slow service, low prices and pretty good food. I am glad we tried this restaurant, but am looking forward to trying out a different establishment next time we are in town.

Go-to order: Papaya salad, hot, Thai style ( if you like pork rinds) ** warning for amateurs-shrimp paste flava! ** basil duck, hot - so yummmmmmy Basil catfish or snapper - whichever fish you like better.  Hot, sweet, Thai, yummy Pad kee Mao, Thai hot!!! -  we get with tofu. **another warning for the weak stomachs, this will make you sweat!!** Only comment we have is there seem to be TWO chefs here.  I'm guessing the main grand PUBA authentic Thai grandma takes off during off peak days so there are two very different Rosded in reality.  You are safe on thur-say I feel but other days you might get the filler.  You will know cause the food comes much sweeter.  Not bad, but not the Grand Puba-5star-styles.  Oh yeah it's a hole in the wall but isn't that a plus?  :)

Listen. Are there fancier more luxurious thai restaurants around? Sure. Will any of them have as good of food at as good a value? The answer is resoundingly no. I have never eaten something at Roseded that wasn't delicious and ridiculously affordable.  The place is tiny so I wouldn't bring all your buds here but the service is great! Staff is warm, charming, and helpful. If you are in the mood for great Thai I'd say go for it, even if you're NOT on a budget.

the service could be better. i got a li'l annoyed that they didn't repeat my order on the phone or when i picked it up. i never saw a receipt and the bag was stapled before she gave it to me. the whole way home i was bitching that our food had better be right. well... it was right. so i need to quit my bitchin'. but if you want chopsticks i guess you have to ask for 'em.  everything we've tried has been yummy: -crazy noodles is a fave of mine, although this last time it wasn't as spicy as i would have liked. -they have several dishes with catfish- can't remember which we've had but it was good. -thai crispy rolls- reminds me of my mom's eggrolls :) -tofu satay -pad see eiw- this is also a usual of mine at thai places. rosded's is up there. -once we had a salad w/ ground chicken and peanut stuff (reminds me of lettuce wraps)- super yummy. but the lettuce got a bit soggy. the best part is that for all this consistenly tasty food, my girlfriend and i can stuff ourselves (just one more bite... okay, one more bite...) and still have plenty left over for both our lunches the next day. and all for 25 buckaroos. that's a steal!

Pad Thai was good. Service was decent and prices were fair. If I am in this part of the city though...I go one block over to Opart...I like the food better over there...but do not count our Rosded...they are a great choice too.
It's my favorite Thai place in the city.  Well, anywhere really.  Very good, and reasonably priced.

What can I say about Rosded? My stomach was in a very happy place after lunch here on a brisk Sunday afternoon. I absolutely love Thai food but was accompanied by two newbies, so I felt it was important to take them someplace legit. Forget atmosphere; Rosded is tiny and unimpressive in that department. The service is friendly, but not over the top. It does not matter. The food is to die for. Rosded has wonderful tom yum soup, and their cucumber salad is refreshing and delicately dressed. I am not a fan of cucumbers, so I have always ignored cucumber salad, but for some reason I tried it today. Much to my surprise, I was literally shoveling them into my mouth. Wonderful. The shrimp shumai came with 2 different dipping sauces, both of which we enjoyed, and the pork satay was moist and flavorful. (Side note: satay comes with a small side of cucumber salad, but you may just need to spend $2 and spring for a 2nd heaping portion.) The pad thai and pad woon sen were among the best I have had, but the real tantalizer was the dish I asked to be delivered extra spicy: the thai basil noodles with beef and wide noodles. The combination of the jalepeno, chili, ground beef, and basil was unlike anything I have ever experienced. My senses actually felt heightened while I was eating this. The noodles were thick and almost like a dumpling in taste and texture, with a slight browned top like a marshmallow. My taste buds were dancing with this one. The thai tea was also a great way to cap off the meal. My guests walked away with lots of leftovers, and the entire meal cost under $50 for 3 people. I will run back to this place.

When it comes to Thai restaurants this one is definitely one of the best. I've been coming to this little place for years and the food is always consistent. For many who are Thai, they're always happy to call this as one of the most authentic Thai places around. There's a dish called "Yen Ta Fo", or words to that effect, that is a very rare dish to get right the way Thailand itself does it, and these people do it right.  So if you want to taste what real Thai taste like for the noodle soup dish called Yen Ta Fo, this is the one. My personal favorite is the Tofu Satay, it's such a tasty piece I could scarf down a dozen, even people who don't like Tofu, I guarantee that you'll probably love this one.  The Yen Ta Fo, the Tofu  Satay, and finallly the Pineapple raisin fried rice I feel are the top choices that you can't go wrong with. Because it's such a small place, the service is usually just one single waiter, but man do they know how to pick their waiters! So the service is really good and accommodating.  All in all, definitely one of the best Thai places around.

I love thai food and this has been the best authentic and inexpensive thai food I've had since I moved to the Chicago area. My Thai friend took me here last weekend to check it out because she's been going to this place since she was a baby and has been going ever since, so I knew it HAD to be good.  This small authentic thai restaurant is one of those hole in the wall places in the city that only thai food lovers seem to really know about because you could walk by this place and not even notice it was there! So keep your eyes open :P I would recommend the chicken pad sea ewe(spicy), red curry, fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce or plum sauce and the pad thai! I normally don't get pad thai at a thai restaurant because it doesn't usually taste that great, but the pad thai is wayyyy better here. So you should try it out! I definitely want to come back to this place before I move~ I'm really going to miss it :(
So we have been back,  They seem to have righted the ship.  Order off the authientic Thai menu.  Do not worry, staff will t ranslate and the food is fantastic....

Went here last night because of all the other positive Yelp reviews.  The food was great.  The wait time to get our food.. not so much.  It took forever for our food to arrive.  There was one poor overworked guy  taking care of all the tables (all of the tables were taken save two - its a small place).  I don't know if one of the servers was off sick or what, but we had our menus for about 20 minutes before he was able to come back and take our order.  I'm not trying to hate or anything, and the food we had (thai basil noodles and pepper steak, pot stickers for an appetizer) was delish, but it just too entirely too long to arrive.  I might consider coming back on a weekday when its less busy.

Rosded! Or as I like to pluralize it, Rosdedssss! I like thai, a lot. And this restaurant is so far the best thai that I have had in the city.  #1 their Tom Yum soup is the best. It is not too sweet but so tangy. Only advice is dont order as entree with noodles and fishballs. The fishball things were not my favorite, I just want to drink up the soup, who needs noodles when you have all that yummmy broth!? #2 their is some kind of noodle dish, i think the crazy something noodles that are really delicious, I am pretty sure if i remember right they are thick noodles with basil, jalapenos and loaded with veggies. These noodles are another favorite on the menu.  I have also tried the pad thai, pepper steak, mussels, duck and pad woon sen. I am never disappointed when I leave Rosdeds. I am craving some Tom Yum now.  Did I mention how tiny this place is? Which I really like. One waiter and he is always there. And the prices are lower than any other thai place so far eaten at.

I am so glad I gave this place another chance. The first time I ate here, I had Pad  thai.it  was nothing to write home about. I had the Panang Curry with tofu tonight and it was very good, some of the best I have ever had,in fact. It was spicier than most,but...in a good way! I will be back to have more of that delicious curry. The Cucumber salad is also fresh and the perfect blend of sweet,tangy and crispy.The best part? Nice portion size and a great bargain!

Wonderful! Great food, and with the biggest portions and lowest prices of all the Thai places around Lincoln Square.  Also very fast--I usually do pickup, and 20 minutes is the usual time from call to pickup.  Friendly staff, and family-owned too I believe.

This place is just as good as I remembered it since the last time I visit.  I love their affordable menu and it's something I miss when I'm back at home in the burbs.  You can pretty much order an entre and a drink (get a Thai ice tea) for under $10 which is amazing for being in the city.   Tom Yum soup is delicious here and have that sourness that I love.  Too many places don't make it sour enough and overcompensate on the sugar.  Pad See Eww is sweet.  There is one other yellow noodle dish that I can't remember the name but it was quite salty. In that case, I just asked for some rice to eat it with and it was fine.   I say go here and give it a try if you like Thai food.  Your wallet will like you for it.

Great food at a great price!  This is my new favorite Thai in Lincoln Square :) Carry out was great since we live down the street. Catfish with basil and sweet hot sauce.  Was great!  I only wish the serving was bigger.  Oh and the side of rice it came with was teeny tiny, I had to eat my own rice for the second half of my meal.  Maybe it's more for dining in.   Crazy noodles.  They were pretty good, it kinda made me want to try their pad thai-  I bet they're better at that. Nam Sod.  It was good but the salad got soggy.   Best part was this was all $23 and some leftovers.  I can't wait to go back!
Delicious.  Would recommend this to anyone looking for a no-hassel night of Thai food.  Very cozy & small quarters, which I liked. The BYOB is a plus as well.  Loved it.

My girlfriend has been bugging me to bring her back to Rosded for a few weeks now. It's been more than five years since we last ate there but it wasn't for any particular reason. It just sort of fell off our radar. The main reason we came back is because they have "the best pad thai" that my girlfriend has ever tasted...and she wanted to see if it still was top dog. With the pad thai on it's way, I ordered the pork larb salad [which is essentially minced pork with red onions, pepper flakes, and mint on a bed of lettuce]. The pad thai is quite different than what I've tasted at other thai joints: it's sweet. Not a bad thing, but it was surprising to me. It also lacked most of the other ingredients typically found in pad thai [an abundant amount of bean sprouts, carrots, cabbage, etc]. So, I thought it was okay. It did, however, bring back memories for the girlfriend, who thought it tasted just as she remembered. The service was ok. The waitress was not very talkative or anything. She did refill our drinks often. Besides taking our order, there was no communication exchanged. Overall, food was good, service was ehh. Probably will be back in the future, maybe in another five or so years.

This is the Thai place that your parents brought you for when you were a kid. It's been around that long. The space is small and unassuming, but the food is ALWAYS right on the money. Stop in, try a Thai Iced Coffee and the Thai Crazy Noodles and enjoy one of the best Thai meals you'll ever have.

Absolutely love it as far as Thai goes. and love the interior as well...in that something about the atmosphere is....i dunno, discreet??? basically you can have a conversation in there and kind of feel like you adn your friend are by yourselves. very strong n cozy atomosphere of Nobody Cares What You Do. Maybe it's only cause it's not so crowded but i really think there's more to it than that. I wish I could be more specific, but you know how some places, even if there's no crowd, you kind of feel like anyone else there is a TAD too interested in what you're doing? (no we are not crazy boisterous types) but i think (hope) you know what I mean. at any rate, at Rosded you feel very much left in peace....despite that the wait staff is attentive and polite :)

I have been to many many many thai restaurants in Chicago and I can honestly say they consistently deliver the most delicious thai food in the city. I highly recommend the kratium chicken (garlic chicken thai style) or the salmon ginger dish. SUPER GOOD!

I've lived around the corner for years, but due to the plethora of Thai places within a mile of my apt, I hadn't been to Rosded yet. I finally made it there last night and had a great experience. We started with the spring rolls in peanut sauce. The spring rolls were your standard fare - but the peanut sauce was delicious. It was really thick and flavorful, way better then I've had most places. My dining companioin and I both got the crispy basket (mine with tofu, hers with shrimp) and we both loved it! The sauce was awesome - perfectly seasoned with just a hint of spice. The tofu was cooked wondefully - a little crispy on the outside but soft on the inside (I don't like it when its too hard or too soft all the way through). The dish came with lots of noodles and just the right amount of veggies. It's a big dish - so come with an appetite! The service was good too. It's a small place, maybe 10 tables so it's not hard to get the attention of the server if you need something. It's also a BYOB and Provenance is right next door so you can pick up your wine right before you dine! (There's also a larger liquor store about a block away in case wine's not your thing).  I'll definitely be heading back to Rosded sooner rather then later to check out some of the other items on the menu.

Awesome authentic Thai food with good-sized portions and reasonable prices?! Sounds too good to be true? Well it isnt!  Rosed is all of that and more!  I like their Pad-Thai (egg noodle or regular), Pad-see-ew, and Chili/Basil Chicken. Excellent!    Rosded has a different taste from other Thai restaurants such as Spoon and Opart. I can't explain it really except they use different spices and their pad-thai is sweeter tasting.  The persons at the counter are actually glad to see you and don't have attitudes unlike the other 2 Thai restaurants in the neighborhood.

Shockingly enough, they did it to me. I live so deliciously close to Sticky Rice, another glorious favorite, I never thought I'd stray. Then I heard about Rosded.  I can only handle so much positive word of mouth about a restaurant before I have to try it for myself, and oh my heavens! The "Rosded Soup"  is basically a Thai version of Vietnamese Pho.  It is very, very good.  Don't drink out of the plastic to-go container while you drive. There is also a seafood curry that has my cohabitator hooked (thanks for the clever phrase, US Census!) I was disappointed not to find a menu online.  I may scan one and share it somewhere so I don't have to worry about losing it. I'm still giving this baby 5 stars.  If you like to experiment with the plethora of special Thai spots sprinkled throughout the city, give 'er the ol' stop-by. Oh:  and it's as small as the little end of nothin' sharpened!

If you were to try one Thai place in Chicago, this would be it.  Sorry, Arun, but  this place is the real thing.  And by real, I mean an old Thai lady cooking the food in the little kitchen only an eye shot away.  Definitely the most authentic place I've been to.  You gotta try it.
Standard fare. Hurried service. Tiny, and not exactly clean-looking restaurant. Inexpensive prices. Perhaps I'll try it again for takeout.

This place seriously has some amazing thai food! It might look like a tiny hole in the wall but the food is to die for! I just love the autheticity about it. One sad thing is that they aren't open on Mondays. :( sad face. I order the basil chicken with noodles and I've had their crazy spicy noodles (or something similar sounding) and they were both delicious. The owners are very nice and they will remember your face. My mom is officially known as the one who doesn't drink water. It's always nice to be remembered. So definitely don't hesitate to come here for some amazing thai food. You won't regret it.

This place is seriously so fantastic.  Don't get Thai food anywhere else.  Seriously, why anybody would do that, I cannot say. We had an app of fish cakes, which were tasty, but I was sidetracked by this peanut-cucumer salad situation that was just meant to be like, a garnish probably, but I could not stop eating it.  When the garnish is amazing, you know the restaurant is special. We got pad thai, Massaman curry, and something with calamari - probably referred to as "squid" on the menu.  Holy CRAP the curry.  it was amazing.  The likes of which I have never had before.  I kind of want some now.  And the pad thai was great too, certainly the best I've had of such a basic dish. This place just runs circles around most other Thai places.  Oh and it's like, significantly cheaper.  if only they delivered!

You know how people say it's usually hole-in-the-wall places that have the best food? Rosded reaffirms this theory for Thai food. Inside was small and simple but the food was unpretentious and traditional. It's also comforting to see the restaurant packed with Thai folks. I've paid a lot for Thai before and Rosded is by far the best bang for your buck. Tried the fried spring rolls, chicken pad thai, and the nam tok (beef salad) and they were beyond satisfying. Best of all, BYOB baby. I didn't know this when I went there but rest assure I'll have my Singha ready to go for my next visit.

We followed the advice of many Yelpers, and went to this "diamond in the rough" restaurant.  The dining area is nothing special, the bathroom has a space heater next to the toilet so you don't get chilly, and we had to ask for rice...a lot.  However, the food was great!  And the best part was the bill.  There were five of us, we ordered two appetisers, i think the bill was around $50.  Without question i'll visit again when I'm in chicago.

Excellent Thai food in a Hmmmm, yeah, kinda dirty dining room.   We stumbled in here by accident this afternoon when checking out the 'Square.  First time we walked by around 2 it was full (maybe 10 tables?  Small.) so that was a good sign. Got back around 3 after window shopping (Mmmmmm Gene's Sausage Samples .....) and ordered. Thom Ka soup - Six Flags My Green Curry - not to flavorful or hot, but decent.  I'd order something else, it wasn't as hot or flavorful as Thai Sookdee does it in Evanston Flowers' Pineapple fried rice - Delish. I was trying to break away from always getting pad see eiw at Thai places, so of course after I order dude walks by with a place of it that smells AWESOME so next time I'm getting that. I'd say go to Rosdad if you're in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't necessarily make a special trip to go there.  Expect it to be a little dirty but whatever, world keeps a-spinnin'. Also the front door opens in but the interior door opens out.  Awkward, so if there's a fire, just make sure you get to the door first.  Just saying. Five flags.  More flags, more fun.

i love this place!  we drive out of our way to get here.  everything on the menu is authentic and delicious.  prices are also very easy on the wallet.  this is my absolute favorite thai restaurant in the city.

One of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city.  The flavors and tastes from all the food here is exceptional.  It is located in the heart of Lincoln Square where there are an influx of various Thai restaurants but this place tops the list.  From the pad dishes to the crab rangoon to the rice dishes to the curry dishes, you couldn't ask for a better Thai food experience.  Very affordable as well.  My only wish was if there were free parking...especially if I am just ordering carry out.

I saw the warning signs, you never see Asians eating in here, even looking through the window you can see that they substitute proper Southeast Asian vegetables with cheaper American frozen vegetables, and not a single haole reviewer here warns about the spicy-hot levels.  And yet, I get dragged in here from time to time by friends, because there is some great shopping around here and the two other neighborhood Thai restaurants aren't especially good either.  But I'm not going back this time, their service, portion sizes have been decreasing, which is fine, I need to lose weight, but as a bonafide Asian, I just can't handle the insult of smaller white rice portions, and being charged per tiny little bowl for each additional bowl of white rice.  They don't even notice when you're out of rice.   Outrageous.  If you want to avoid authentic Thai cuisine, you could still find pseudo-Thai restaurants with better parking availability.   By the way, the boutique pet supply store next door has the absolute best cat nip in town, according to my cats.
We were brought here by our Thai friend, who ordered for us in Thai, so I cannot tell you what we ate. EVERYTHING was very fresh and good! We were surprised for such a hole in the wall!

This place was great! You know a restaurant is good when it's super small but on a Sunday night is packed full of people. The chicken pad thai was delicious and huge portioned. The shrimp rolls were good. Also, the egg rolls are really good...they are huge and have some extra flavoring, I think maybe a pinch of cinnamon or something. Very good.  Very reasonably priced too - the Pad Thai was $5.95. Excellent. Thai Iced Tea was great too. It's also BYOB, can't go wrong there.

Went here two Saturdays ago (Nov 7th) while in Lincoln Square for other business as we have other times before and thought I'd finally Yelp since I remembered to grab a to-go menu. On a bang-for-buck or taste basis, the best I've been to in a long time. We park adjacent in the parking lot on Western: only $1 an hour, newly paved and always parking spaces--easy. Thai grocery store next door for those who want to double dip. Also think it's the Brown line that stops literally across the street.  I ordered the Roseded Ball ($4.25) and my panraya got the Crispy Tofu ($3.25) for starters. Actually, nothing spectacular about the beef meatballs--about the same as we get for home from another Asian grocery joint, but good. While not generally a tofu fan, these are good and not fried to a crisp, but just enough to brown the outside--puffy and chewy, good stuff. As always, I try the Thai Crazy Noodles (akak pad kee mao or drunken noodles, $5.95) and here you won't be disappointed. I always get beef to start and then if I like, on subsequent visits I'll get chicken. Excellent taste, good sized portion, little residual oil (a big peeve of mine), and veyr tuk! Authentic look and taste--on par with a couple of places I tried in Thailand (Chiang Mai, Bangkok) during the summer. My wife got the Yen Ta Fo ($5.95) which is a multi-fishy soup with funny looking mushrooms--it ain't your Farang Tom Yum variety. She swears by it here...and she's Thai by birth and 25 years, so FWIW. Service is good, and they have a Thai menu as well for Thai readers (of which I'm not). Tiny little place, maybe seats 30 max, but we've never had a problem getting a seat right away, though we don't generally hit it at rush hour. Like most Thai joints, Diet Coke only in the can (my only gripe). Cheapest Thai I can recall, and I search out Thai all around the country. Other than ordering a whole snapper, the most expensive thing on the extensive menu is $8.95----EIGHT NINETY FIVE MAX! Don't think lunch comes with the usual free appetizers at the expense of smaller portions, but see previous sentence. Been here 4 times now, never disappointed, always consistent.

If you're looking for charm and decor, wrong place.  If you're looking for a good Thai meal, with reasonable prices and generous portions, this is the place. I've been here twice and the product is consistent.  Reasonably fast service a nice spicy meal and out the door for two with appetizers for $25.  Can't complain.  They make a nice spicy basil with chicken, the fish with sweet chili basil is great, the pineapple curry with shrimp is good (if not a bit too sweet), the shumai get the job done. It's a little off the beaten path and small, but this is a great little gem in Lincoln Square.

I stepped outside of my box this evening. Usually I opt for Opart, but I decided to cheat on her with Rosded. This quaint 'lil Lincoln Square restaurant is a little tighter inside, and has a warm feeling to her. Take it out, she says---NO DELIVERY! This was fine, as I live close by and it wasn't cold or raining, for once.  I chose the pineapple fried rice with chicken. Wifey had the cashew chicken. I was pleasantly surprised, and feel as though Rosded is equally as good as Opart---BUT, cheaper:)  VERY generous portions, great flavor, and quality ingredients makes this place a winner.  *The only reason Rosded doesn't get 5 stars is because the entrees didn't have any spice. I'm sure this could be requested---next time, I'll ask. I'm sure I'll be back very soon!  Opart may have some serious competition...

BYOB.  One of the best Thai food locations around.  The price makes the meals that much better.  You can get two meals, an appetizer and some soup for around $24.  You would never guess this restaurant would have such great food, but it is amazing.  I liked one of the spicy chicken noodle dishes and the wife enjoys some of the vegetarian options.  They have a soup that feeds about 4 for under $5.  I believe they have a very minimal corking fee if any.  This is definitely our new go to Thai restaurant.

This is probably my favorite thai place that I've been to in the city, so far.  The first bonus: It's so cheap!  There isn't much, if anything, that is over $7 on their menu.  The quality of the food is great - it is much more authentic than many other thai restaurants I've been to.  I think a lot of people use them for take-out, but I've dined-in here twice, and have loved everything that I've tried so far, including taking bites from my husbands plate.  :)  I highly recommend!

Had dinner at the restaurant once and went for pick up another time. The food here is excellent and a great bang for the buck! I ordered the nam sod (very good), chickem musaman and a side of rice noodles and it was less than $15! Not much for atmosphere but it's BYOB which is nice. My only complaint is the amount off rice they give for a take out order. It was a very small container and would have been annoying had I not gotten a side of the rice noodles also (for $1). Would definitley recommend this place for take out or for a very casual dinner.

I've only had food here once and it was take-out so this review may not have much to offer...but...GD, it was tasty! I was working at SQJ's newest location (which is next door to Rosded) for the day and my coworker suggested Thai for lunch.  I'm always down for Thai. I ordered the red curry, which they call something else on the menu.  I asked for it to be extra spicy 'cause thats how I roll.   This curry was AMAZING!  So spicy, creamy and full of veggies and chicken.  Cheap, too.   I cant tell you about the service or atmosphere but I can tell you that next time I am working on the northside I am getting Thai take-out from Rosded.

Tasty and affordable. I have been here a few times over as many years, and after coming here a few weeks ago, I was asking myself why I waited so long in between visits.  The interior is comfy but nothing fancy.   Service is quick and friendly.   And the food?  Good variety, very tasty items, and everything is very reasonably priced.   Now I want a big bowl of tom kha.  I will be back.
The panang beef will make you a believer. 'nuff said.

P.W.C.N (Pregnant Wives Crave Noodles).  Which works out great for me, we get to go out for Thai more often.  This weekend's excursion took us to Lincoln (Lincoln Square).  We stopped into Rosded for some dinner.   BTW what do you think the origin of that name?  Did they misspell rosebed?  Or did they mean Rose-dead (SO EMO!)  It's probably neither.   What I do know is that they serve up some good Thai.  The won ton soup was very good.  So many good dishes to choose from.  I went with the Rosded Supreme which is choice of meat w/ hot chili sauce and stir-fried veggies.  Good times.  Didn't try my wife's pad woo sen, but it looked good and she inhaled it, so it must have been good. We rounded out the evening with a view of 500 Days of Summer at the Davis, again, with the emo.

There's so many Thai restaurants in Chicago, so why pick Rosded? Every Thai restaurant has it's own specialty...Rosded makes a good pad thai, but this is not why I come here.  I come here for the CATFISH. Spicy Basil Catfish!!!!  Sweet savory succulent spicy supercalafragilisticexpealidocious!!!   EVEN IF YOU HATE EATING FISH, try it...seriously.  It's listed as "Catfish" on the menu.  It's all about THE SAUCE.  Let's face it, sauce can make it or break it.  The sauce on the catfish is the bomb-diggity!!!  Sometimes I ask for extra sauce.  It's also good if you ask for lime wedges on the side to change up the taste a bit....so good!!!   You can get the same dish @ Rosded Too on Waukegan Road in Morton Grove. CATFISH!! CATFISH!!! CATFISH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I must admit that Rosded [still unsure of how to pronounce it so I renamed it Rose-Dead from that day forward] has a TON of competition.  Chicago supposedly has the most bars per capita than any other city in the world...and I'd say that Thai restaurants is next on board!   I came to Rosded with the fellow Yelper, Claire S., to catch up on our lives.  We were a bit weary walking in the door being that it was empty at that time and everything looks a bit grimy and simply not as clean as it should be.  I turned a blind eye to the ambiance like I had already done with the semi-ride waitress and tried to pay more attention to our conversation.   As the food came we dug in.  The spring rolls were mediocre, nothing out of this world.  I had the Pad See Eiw which was also just average (nothing like Noodles in the Pot/Joys/Opart Thai House).  Claire, however, had the Pad Thai which tasted as authentic and perfect as I could ever image it to be.  It's an EXPLOSION of peanuts!  Prepare your body for an exuberant protein intake.   Point made: I would come to Rosedead solely for the Pad Thai, nothing more! A side story: Two hours after Claire S & I left and were already at my apartment drinking green tea I had realized I had left my CVS groceries in Rosded.  Picture it...Me on the phone trying to explain to someone who speaks one of the most difficult and unique languages I know of, Thai, that! -Hi I left my groceries... [damn, big word] -Plastic Bag with vitamins and a prescription... [darn, too much description] -Shopping Items... [could still hear her confusion possibly due to me speaking too quickly] -My bag...on chair...near window...Be there in 5 minutes.  Thank you! Thankfully my bag was still there but phew was it an experience of "lost in translation."

I'm not feeling the reviews up here. This was by far one of my last choices in the millions of Thai places in this city. Service was not good. She was annoyed rude. Prices were super cheap, so that's cool. Food was not awful, but NOT good. I got hot peppers on rice. Really I think that's what it was called. I get rice dishes quite a bit at Thai places, and this was totally different. If this is what authentic is, well then, it's bad. I got a plate full of white rice that was practically dry. There was no sauce. The "hot" peppers were green and red bell peppers. (whoohoo. Boringville) And the broccoli pieces and onions were hardly cooked. It was like a pile of plain, barely cooked veggies on plain, unsauced rice. WTF. i could have "cooked" this at home in 3 minutes. The reason I LOVE Thai food is because of the complex spiciness, the lemoniness, the slight fishiness, the veginess...yeah this had none of that.  Sad, I won't be returning. I'd rather go to Royal Thai, Spoon, opart, Oscar, or Kan Pou any day.

I just got back from my first dinner at Rosded and I have to say, it's my favorite place for Thai in the area.  The Thai Tea was amazing -- very strong, sweet, and smooth, a perfect way to end a salty/spicy/savory meal.  We got the fish cakes, which were OK, and a glass noodle salad, which was delicious, to start with.  We weren't expecting both to be entree portions, but who can complain about too much good food? The entrees here were the real treat.  I got the Thai Crazy Noodles, which were spiced well with noodles that were ever-so-slightly springy and soaked in a delicious brown sauce.  My husband got Spicy Basil Squid, and he loved the fact that it was actually spicy.  I don't usually like squid but this stuff was incredibly tender, especially considering the price. We came starving and left stuffed to our eyeballs with smiles on our faces.  We're coming back very soon!

I recommend this place to all my friends who enjoy amazing Thai food. I've been coming here for years. Their Wonton soup is the best I ever had and my all time fave from here is the Thai Iced tea. And I also love their spring rolls... Yummy ;)

Not only is this one of the cheapest thai places I know (out of those... what now.... 4? 5? thai places in the square?) it is a homey, pleasant food experience and the food there is unbeatable.  Though I still do island hop from Spoon to Opart to Rosded every now and then (these are all good thai places along Western) I always keep coming back to this place. Some of my favorite dishes there are the Pad See Ew, Tom Kha, and many of their vegetable rice combos. Makes for a really great cheap date, with great food.  Farmers market on tuesdays is great too, right across from there in the morning :D

Rosded is my second least favorite Thai in the city.* Now, don't get the two stars give you the wrong idea, the service was fine, the staff was very nice, but this review is based solely on the food. The first time I tried this place was when I was in eighth grade, and only just starting to like remotely interesting food, so I assumed the reason I thought poorly of this place was just because I was still a little picky. Then I started dating a guy who loved Rosded, so we went, and I ordered the pad thai (as I always do, that's a lot of what I judge Thai restaurants on), and I still really disliked it, to the point of putting my fork down after a bite. Instead I filled up on appetizers, which weren't bad but nothing special. If you want Thai in Lincoln Square, I don't think this is the place. There are so many delicious options on Western, it seems like a waste to go here. *Least favorite gave me food poisoning.

I was lucky enough to grab dinner here with my fellow Yelper, Richie D.  The food wasn't bad, but it also wasn't my favorite Thai food in the city.  The flavors were good, but the food seemed a little too greasy.  Also, the place could use some cleaning.  The front door (looked like white vinyl) was filthy.  As Richie noted at the time: not a good first impression.  And the inside seemed boarder line dirty as well.  However, the service was good and you really can't beat the prices-with many entree prices under $6.

Good authentic Thai food at very reasonable prices. Basil Fried Rice, Tofu Fried Rice, Pad Thai, Red Snapper, and Shrimp Rolls are just a few of the family favorites. Service is always fast and the portions are relatively large for the price. Only downfall is no delivery in our area.  : (

i love thai food.  and i love FRESH thai food even more.  rosded is one of my favorite thai restaurants because of this. the prices are so very reasonable, the service is always pretty good (lots of refills on my water glass), and the food is outstanding.  the restaurant is tiny, which sometimes means that walking to the register to pick up my carry-out order is a bit of an obstacle course, but i've never had to wait for a table.   if i could eat the chicken satay appetizer and red curry with tofu every single day, i would.  i might be ENORMOUS, but i sure would be happy.  :)

This is the first place I had Thai food (years and years ago) and after trying them again not long ago I found the food was still delicious; Ample portions made with fresh ingredients. My only complaint is how small it is inside.

I've gone here three times and have tried different dishes. The last time I went with three omnivores who weren't familiar with thai food. They loved it. The dishes were ginger chicken, pad see eww, and cashew chicken. They were also big fans of the Thai ice tea. Nothing adventurous but they were quite happy and the dishes were good sizes. I wasn't a huge fan of the green curry (I can never remember which one I prefer...). The tom kha was good. No complaints on my end, especially since it's conveniently located by the Western Brown line.

Of the five or so Thai restaurants within walking distance of Lincoln Square, Rosded is by far my favorite.  My husband and I get take-out there every couple of weeks and it's always, always delicious.  Just the warm, happy smell of the place when I go to pick up the food we've ordered makes me feel better after a tough day.  Their curry chicken soup with noodles is like comfort in a bowl. On the handful of occasions when we've gone to eat in the restaurant, rather than ordering take-out, the servers are always friendly and helpful.  Just a note, though--food often comes out of the (very small) kitchen one entree at a time, which is great for sharing, but not so great if each diner has ordered individual dishes.
This is authentic Thai food in perfect portions. The have an extensive fish menu (at least 2 pages) 99% of entrees are under $10. I just wish they delivered!

My family and I are addicted to Thai food, and this is our favorite Thai restaurant in Lincoln Square. My sisters are addicted to the Pad Thai, while my mother always goes for the fried snapper. My dad and I love all of the curries we've ordered here! Plus the food is slightly cheaper than the nearby Thai restaurants on Western Ave. Although I love this restaurant I have to take away one star for a few of reasons. They simply do not have enough room to seat everyone during peak dinner times and there's not really anywhere inside to stand to wait for a table. Plus, they don't deliver and I find myself consistently disappointed with their carry-out.  If you're looking to dine at a Thai restaurant in Lincoln Square and there's a table free at Rosded, I highly recommend you check it out.

Rosded is by far one of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city.  The decor is no frills and you won't find any fancy upscale fusion going on here.  What you will find are some very flavorful and authentic Thai dishes with friendly service and reasonable prices.  My favorites include the Chicken Satay, Basil Chicken, Pad Thai, and the BBQ Pork Wonton Soup.
a friend suggested we meet here for dinner.  looked up the reviews here on yelp, and agreed to rosded.  excellent food.  cheap prices.  cozy atmosphere.

The instant I walked into Rosded, I thought to myself, "This place is the real deal." The pungent aroma and homey decor enveloped and comforted me. So from the moment I sat down, I had high expectations, and Rosded did not disappoint. Luckily, I dined with a group of eight or so, several of whom were regulars, so I had the opportunity to try many dishes. I was introduced to som tum, or papaya salad, which I've now tried at a couple other establishments that failed to come close to Rosded's flavor, freshness, and spiciness. I've never been a big fan of pad thai, but someone special-ordered it with wide rice noodles (one of my biggest weaknesses) and it was fantastic. Other reviewers, most of whom seem to be fond of pad thai in general, have complained that Rosded's is too saucy, but I think that's exactly why I liked it. The salmon curry, a house specialty, was off-the-charts good. The pad kee mao with tofu, one of the dishes by which I often gauge a Thai restaurant, was merely good. The deliciousness of all the other dishes, however, inspired in me the goodwill to overlook a weakness that would cause me to write off many Thai places. I don't make it out to Lincoln Square too often, so I have yet to try Opart or Spoon. When I finally do, they'll have to work pretty hard not to be upstaged by this unassuming neighbor.

We tried Rosded with a friend who had lived in Thailand for a little while, and he thought it was authentic -- but more like street fare or home cooking, rather than like what you would get in a formal restaurant.  The interior reflects the "comfort food" ethic -- it's small and casual and probably gets uncomfortable when crowded. But when we were there it was pretty relaxed.  The other reviews here seem pretty accurate. Don't go here if you are looking for upscale ambiance or fast service (and yes, different foods come out at different times). Try Rosded if you are looking for good value (e.g. huge portions), you're not in a hurry, and you like your pad thai saucy.
