I have been to Rosded many times and it is one of my favorite Thai restaurants. It is small and the decor is nothing to write home about but the food is always good and authentic. I love the pineapple curry, the chicken with basil leaves,  and the roasted chicken. The roasted chicken does take 30-40 minutes to prepare. It is not what I would consider a typical Thai dish but is worth the wait. I also love to see that Thai people actually eat in this restaurant, which definitely is a bonus for me.  The owner is always the one to serve us and is very nice and helpful.
I wandered into this cute restaurant because the menu had salmon, a fish rarely found in Thai restaurants. The salmon was tasty but the service was a bit slow.

I stopped in here on my way home from shopping in Lincoln Square.  I glanced at the menu and the prices are pretty cheap - actually, almost no entree is more than $6.50.  Awesome!! So I decided to pick up some takeout for my boyfriend and me.  The restaurant was pretty empty - only one group eating in and one group waiting for take out.  The space is small and very cozy - the tables are decorated nicely and there is a lot of Thai art on the walls.  It's a very cute little restaurant.  The service was quick and the man who took my order was very friendly.  It only took about 15 minutes to get my order ready so I went next door to do some shopping.   The food was pretty good.  I ordered the Pad See Ew with tofu and my boyfriend had Pad Thai with chicken.  The Pad See Ew was actually really good - some of the best I've had in awhile.  However, the Pad Thai was pretty bad.  It was way too - peanut-y or something.  I couldn't really put my finger on what was wrong with the dish, but it just wasn't very good.  I would never order it from this restaurant if we went back even though I love Pad Thai.  We also got some spring rolls which were pretty good - they weren't rolled very well (they kept falling apart) but the dipping sauce was excellent.  All in all, a pretty average experience.  The prices are cheap enough that I may go back just to try some other dishes.

Are you all on CRACK?!?! The best thing about this place was it's soap! It smelled great. My sister's shrimp fried rice had shit in the shrimp and the actual rice smelled like dog! My food was alright, but there's better than this..like Penny's!! If you want to feel sick, go to Rosden. I don't know why there was a sticker on the door saying people on Yelp liked this place, but now I see it got good ratings for some reason.

A couple of girlfriends and I came to this place after a night of watching a movie in Evanston. My one friend is Thai and she said this was her "go to" place for authentic Thai food. This made me doubly excited as I love going to unassuming places that are recommended by people who are experts in their food.  Thai food is one of my favorite fares because it incorporates sweet with spicy and sometimes sour and sweet. Pad thai is one of my favorite dishes (I know -- how American and boring!) and it gives me a pulse check of the restaurant. I ordered pad thai with tofu with extra lemon. When it came out, it was about double the portion size I am used too - which was great because I was starving. However, when I looked at the noodles, it was SUPER soggy. Not what I am used to -- AT ALL. It was really moist and it was almost as if the noodles were overcooked.  It may have been an off night or the fact that we came in JUST as they were about to close. Who knows? Maybe I'll come back and give another dish a chance...

Oh NO! We got takeout, twice, and it was horrible! Well, my pineapple curry was fine but seemed to be lacking in general flavor, buy my sister's pad thai was terrible. It had no taste except overwhelmingly peant butter. Where is the lemongrass Rosded, where is the lime? Why did you phone in the most basic of American Thai dishes? We haven't gone back. I will, but not for awhile. Time to diversify in my Lincoln Square Thai offerings.

Rosded is one of the finest examples of Chicago's small, unassuming, authentic ethnic restaurants. I had to upgrade to 5 stars because it is small, and kinda drab compared to O'Part, but in retrospect, that contributes rather than detracts from its charm. In Chicago, you can pay what you want for food, and there are a lot of choices, but if you choose to go to Rosded for some Thai food after looking in the window your expectations will probably be exceeded. You know you're sacrificing fine dining ambiance for some of what the diners from SE asia expect to get. You score!

I can't help but give Rosded five stars. My wife and I either eat in or carry out once a week. A favorite night is grabbing dinner and seeing a movie at the Davis. Love the pad thai, thom kha soup, pa nang curry (with tofu).

Somehow this little gem escaped the notice of my wife and I for over a year.  What a terrible shame, because this is really one of Lincoln Square's best kept secrets. The dining area is unpretentious.  Nothing fancy, but very peaceful, cozy, and surprisingly quiet for the size and number of tables.  Lots of pictures of monks and Thai royalty.  The staff is congenial and welcoming without being overbearing.   And the FOOD!  I'm not Thai snob, but I'll rant and rave about the Panang Beef all day long.  For me, it was one of those moments in life where you try something new and discover a craving you never knew you had.  Now I will always have a special place in my heart that can only be filled with Rosded's Panang Beef. Rosded is right across the street from the Western stop of the Brownline, so if you have a CTA card you have no excuse for missing out on this diamond in the rough.

I love this little spot.  The food is great.  The wonton soup is fantastic and the red curry is so good.  And the price...come on for 20 bucks two people can eat and have enough for lunch the next day.  The dining room is small and really basic, but then again, I'm not there for the ambiance.  Finally BYOB, enough said.

Rosded served me one of the gnarliest meals of my life.  The plate arrived with a nice big hair in the middle of it and when I told the owner I didn't want it and wasn't hungry anymore, he had the kitchen make another one and serve it to me after my friends had finished eating. So, I guess he did try to do the right thing - I'll give him credit for that.  Also, while my pals were (cautiously) eating their food, the waiter saw fit to rummage through two trash bags right by our table on his way out to the dumpster.

I am not going to lie--the food here was okay.  And that's it.  Based on other reviews, I wonder if I was eating in the same place.  Right off the bat, I know I could care less about authentic.  I'm not Thai, I've never been to Thailand, so what do I know about authentic.  I just want some tasty noodles, which I had and, again, they were okay.  Super greasy but still tasty.  In all of my American-ness, I missed that Miso didn't come with an entree...I could've used that. I'm not going to rave about this place.  And I don't live close, so in all likelihood I won't be back.  But is it a bad choice for you?  No.  Good solid Thai place...just like a lot of others around.  Hey...what can I say?

This Thai restaurant is a godsend. Fast, cheap, GOOD food in a convenient location for me (right across the street from me and right in-between the Western L stop and my place). The Thai Crazy Noodles are great (I recommend with Pork), their version of Shrimp Shumai is quite interesting (and good) and the BBQ Pork Wonton Soup was a life saver during winter. I call once I pass Diversy on the Brown Line and my food is ready by the time I get there. So good and convenient that I have yet to go to Opart just down the way after living in Lincoln Square for a year and a half.

This is the Thai restaurant where actual Thai people eat.  I was first introduced to Rosded (pronounced RAW-DEHD) by my ex and his family (Thai).  They won me over with the nam tok,  spicy chargrilled beef with Thai seasoning served on a bed of iceberg lettuce.  It's a no frills place, and yes, the service is more neglect than attention.  Despite all that, the food is amazing and will keep me coming back.  (Side note: They're closed on Mondays!)

Excellent thai food.  This place is as authentic as it could get.  I was introduced to it by one of my friends who is also from Thailand.  Their menu is filled with authentic thai food, and the curries are just so good.   I love the fact that they use authentic ingredients instead of using readily available substitutes -which totally turns me off.    When I was at this restaurant,  I felt like I was back in bangkok sitting at a small family run restaurant down the corner, eating authentic thai food.  Love it - I just wish i lived closser so that I could frequent it more often.

I lived in Lincoln Square for 4 years. I walked past Rosded maybe 500 times. Maybe more. Never once did I walk in. A year after I moved to Logan Square, I finally made it to Rosded as I forgot to change my address for voting purposes. I stopped by my old haunts and finally walked into Rosded and ordered the catfish and red curry.  It was very good. Lost in a land of Spoon and Opart Thai, Rosded is the tortoise in the neighborhood. The crisy catfish in rich red curry will make it into the budget Lent Friday rotation with Los Nopales, Tank Noodle, and Pequods. That is pretty good company.

My favorite Thai restaurant in the city limits.  I have to give Siam House in Niles the slightest of nods for best Thai in the metro area,  but having said that I love Roseded.  My favorite dish there is the Moo Ma Naaw.  Translated that means pork in lime juice, however I would have to say that garlic dominates.  It is not a dish for the timid.  It celebrates all the bold flavors of Thai cuisine.  Sour, salt, and savory are in full effect accented with the sweetness of the pork.  It's addictive qualities were illustrated when a friend was driving his moving van to Minneapolis and ordered it to go to eat during the drive...sans rice...and he wasn't stoned.        As I said...I love this place.  Everything is done well.  I have a family filled with Thai women that are not scared to scrunch their noses and furrow their brows at any Thai dish they consider improperly prepared.  They are freaky with their culinary apptitude.  So as testament to Roseded...they love the place.  Have a drink at Huetten Bar first, buy a bottle of wine and some good beer and have a great night with authentic Thai cuisine, great (for the most part) service, and a warm atmosphere.  For me it's comfort food that I love sharing with friends and family.

I introduced my cousin/roommate Eric to this place awhile back and now he can't get enough.  Eric considers himself to be a Thai food connoisseur, although I've only ever seen him order red curry with chicken.  For what its worth, he was blown away by the red curry at Rosded, and was especially impressed by the authentic heat of the dish.    Eric is the size of a St. Bernard and often complains that his "spicy" food isn't hot enough, and when he asks for spicy food, he means to say that it should be hot enough to humble a dog of his size.  So, fed up with the underwhelming heat at other Thai restaurants, at Rosded Eric explicitly defined his terms to our server, "I don't mean American spicy, I mean Thai spicy".  Thai spicy was exactly what he got, and while mopping his brow he proclaimed Rosded's the best red curry he's had in Chicago.  The Som Tum is generous and excellent, Pad Thai is just good, not special.  If you're into store fronts, you'll love this place, its undeniably warm, cozy, and cheap.

I was so conflicted about writing this review. I want this restaurant to stay in business forever, but I don't want them to be overrun with annoying hipsters that ruin the dining experience for me.   I love this place.  LOVE this place.  The staff is always courteous, nice, helpful, and very welcoming.  This is the most authentic Thai food you will have in the city! It has the best flavoring and isn't "Americanized" in any way.  You can't go wrong with anything! Beware, if you are looking for a trendy Thai restaurant, this is not it.  This is good food in a weird location, and is a restaurant that doesn't put thousands of dollars into their decor. It is what it is, a great restaurant at great prices.  That's all you need.

After ordering take-out from a number of Thai joints in the neighborhood i.e.  Spoon, Opart, I always go back to Rosded for one reason...their Rosded Fried Chicken! Thai fried chicken is soooo mouth watering good, who knew?! I also love their signature Rosded Supreme with pork, which is described as having a spicy sauce but is only mildly spicy (suits my taste) with a hint of sweetness that is brought out by the veggies: cabbage, bean sprouts, pea pods, broccoli, etc. Yummy veggies!! Don't be alarmed though by the oily appearance of the dish (I think it's from the spicy fish sauce) because it doesn't taste greasy.  Other dishes are good not excellent i.e. Rama Chicken, Noodle dishes. Now that I've seen recommendations from the other reviews, I'll have to try expanding my repertoire i.e. catfish.  Their hole-in-the-wall (a dozen tables?) dining room and decor may not be for everyone but I ate only once in the restaurant with my infant son and they were very welcoming and attentive (it wasn't a busy time). Also, if you're an ice cream fan, Coldstone is just around the corner at Lincoln Square. Parking is a breeze with all the metered train parking around.

I love this place! its way better all the other competition on Western.  I was in Thailand for a month. Since then I had multiple cravings for authentic thai food and the place to be is at rosded. The dining room is cozy  but the service sometimes is a hit or a miss.. I'm willing to deal with crappy service for great food.

In a city replete with Thai restaurants, this one stands out. Reasons: 1. No nonsense, utilitarian decor complete with grandpa's-den wood paneling. You say "no atmosphere", I say "totally awesome" 2. A real family business feel 3. Great prices 4. Take a bite of any of the entrees. There's just something special. I don't know if it's a certain spice or WHAT, but Rosded's food just has a burst of something extra that sets it apart from the rest 5. Duck curry! Duck curry! Duck curry!

Rosded, is a nice little hole-in-the-wall restaurant. I have been here about 5 times and have never been disgusted by any of their food. The atmosphere certainly lacks charm, but the food is very solid Thai cuisine. I don't go far out of my way to go here, but I have no problem meeting someone there when they name it as a place they'd like to meet for dinner. The service has always been decent and generally friendly (they'd have to be really crappy to not be able to maintain the 6-8 tables that they have there). One of the reasons why I decided not to give a 4-Star rating, was that there is really nothing on the menu that sticks out as excellent. Usually good Thai restaurants have one dish that really sticks out as exceptional... but nothing really does here. If you're in the mood for decently priced, very standard Thai food... this is the place for you... but if you're looking for a place that is going to impress... this is probably not the best choice out there.

you might miss this tiny thai place in lincoln square among all the overpriced boutiques and german bars. but its oh so good. the food is authentic and not the same old stuff you can find anywhere. the service is a little iffy and the atmosphere is nothing. but the food makes up for it entirely. try the tom yum noodle soup (no sugar) or kao mok kai with chicken. the dipping sauce is soooooo good. give it a shot.

This is hands down the best Thai restaurant in the city. If you want slick decor, this is not you place. If you want friendly service and the largest selection of the best Thai food, you have got to check this out. Pad Thai is perfect (I have found none better), Tom Ka Chicken soup is the only thing my wife could eat while she was pregnant (the ginger I guess) and the Cat fish is a 2 times a year indulgence (it can not be good for you)! It's a hole in the wall atmosphere, but one of my favorite restaurants anywhere.

The yummiest and cheapest Thai place in Chicago.  Just thinking about the Rama noodles (soft rice noodles in a peanut-infused coconut curry) makes my mouth water.  You don't usually associate comfort food with exotic cuisines, but this is among the best comfort food I've ever tasted.  Other dishes, like fried noodles, salads, and soups, are also top notch. They've recently added Thai soft drinks to the menu, which are a lot of fun.

Very good food that is very, very spicy.  I had the green papaya salad with a few friends.  I think that I killed some of my tastebuds on my tongue.  It was so freaking spicy!  I also had the Tom Yum soup, which was good too.

This place rates for its good Thai food and very good prices.  I had lunch here, Chicken Rama Noodle for 5.95, no sides included however...  could have been spicier.  The bad Air Supply song courtesy of liteFM was just low enough so that if you were having a conversation you wouldn't be annoyed by it.  The place is small probably about 12 tables, all adorned with paisley and flower pattern tablecloths covered with plastic.  The little pagoda over the kitchen did not make up for the lack of atmosphere. If you are ordering take-out, bump the rating up to 4 stars

Very good Thai food at really cheap prices. They had a lot more dishes on their menu than I have seen at other places. I had the mussaman curry, which was quite tasty, and an appetizer with sweet and crispy noodles which good as well. I would definitely recommend this place. It is small and BYOB.
great authentic thai food. Price is average, very laid back atmosphere. Make sure to get the Rosded soup.

Good Thai food. No Atmosphere, and service is hit and miss. Went there with a friend today for lunch, and it was just okay. I'm Thai, and spent about 4 years inThailand, and some of their menu items are very authentic. However, some of their menu items were totally made up. (which I don't mind). This place is cheap, and good food. Try the Panang with Shrimp($8) or the Shrimp rolls($4). I would skip the BBQ pork rice dish ($6) if you don't like sweet sauce all over everything on your plate. This is a good place for a quick lunch, but wouldn't bother for dinner or when trying to impress.

My favorite Thai place in Chicago, though I have not been to many.  The catfish with sweet sauce (I forget the name of the dish) is excellent. Apparently they're the only place in town that makes it this way.

Not exactly fancy or romantic (which is why it's missing one star) but the food is authentic and tasty.  I feel like my mom's cooking for me, and it's really casual and laid back.  Some of my favorite dishes are the som tum, pad siew, pad kee mao, pad prik, and steamed fish.  Definitely a great places to carry out from if you don't want to eat in the cramped space!!

This place is known for its noodle dishes.  It's a great place for lunch.  The best thai food restaurant in Lincoln Square and the oldest, been coming here since I can remember, before anyone knew what Thai was.

The Lincoln Square area is known for the German influences in its shops & restaurants, but if you take a good look around, you might be surprised to find that Thai is one of the more prevalent types of cuisine available in that area, there are at least four Thai restaurants within short walking distance of the Western stop on the Brown Line.  Rosded is one of the older Thai establishments in that area, the dining room is small & has a hole-in-the-wall decor, but the Pad Thai is among the best I've ever ordered. Prices are pretty cheap too. The folks that run the place are very polite & friendly.

Don't let the nondescript location and somewhat shabby interior fool you. This little gem has the best authentic Thai food in the city (on par with the much revered Thai Town in Los Angeles). Originally recommended by a friend of Thai descent, it did not disappoint.
